Darren,
   I have updated the prior version of rtNEAT to include your progr=
am 
experiment, and will later upload an updated zip file to replace the 
c=
urrent one in the files area.

   I have been reviewing the code for the ex=
periment in an attempt to 
understand the approach. It appears that a numbe=
r sequence is 
presented on an input, along with additional inputs correspo=
nding to 
various program instructions. Output appears to be threshold appl=
ied 
to select the program instruction w/ highest output. The outputs 
corr=
esponding to the sequence is tested for length and correctness as 
applies =
to the status of the stack. Fitness is computed based upon 
cumulative erro=
r over input sequence. It appears that cost is tracked 
but does not appear=
 to factor into fitness?

   Is this even close? Could you supply the prope=
r explanation?

Thanks,
   Andy

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Darren Izzard=
 <zysyshelp@...> wrote:
>
> 
> >Has anybody converted the contents of the N=
EATWIN2.ZIP, located in 
the 
> >Files area, to MSVC++ 6.0 or .NET? I'm par=
ticularly interested 
> >in "Darren's Program Experiment" contained therein=
.
> 
> It's a while since I uploaded that file, and the experiment you 
> m=
ention was a little disappointing in practice.
> 
> The purpose was to use =
NEAT to evolve networks which would output 
> programs in a simple stack-ba=
sed language to generate given 
sequences 
> of numbers. You may be wonderi=
ng: why make the network generate a 
> program to do it rather than have th=
e network generate the 
sequences 
> directly? Mainly because it's really h=
ard to reverse-engineer the 
> algorithms networks are using and understand=
 how they're working, 
and 
> it would be more practical in some ways to ev=
olve routines in a 
form 
> closer to conventional programming languages.
>=
 
> The real difficulty comes down to finding a good representation of 
a 
=
> program which the network can output. The Program Experiment tried 
to 
>=
 have the network build up the program instruction by instruction, 
able 
>=
 to move back and forth through the list to change instructions as 
> neede=
d. This was, in some ways, the inverse of the roving eye 
method 
> for inp=
uts, and I had hoped it would mean a program-generator could 
be 
> evolved=
 incrementally. The main problem was that there was such a 
huge 
> jump in=
 complexity required between a simple, useless program which 
> just return=
ed the average of the sequence (or some other simple 
> output, such as a c=
ounter) and a meaningful one which actually 
> calculated a value.
> 
> The=
refore, a better representation would have to be found where 
these 
> jump=
s would be minimised. One possibility which did occur would be 
to 
> make =
the transformations the network could apply to the list of 
> instructions =
more sophisticated, a bit like the ones ADATE applies 
to 
> programs it ev=
olves.
> 
> At any rate, I now use SharpNeat (which naturally works quite w=
ell 
> under VS.NET!) although I haven't recreated anything like the 
Progr=
am 
> Experiment yet, simply because I haven't thought of a better way of 
=
> doing it.
> 
> --Darren
>
